children.name: issue
children.definition: a subject or problem that is often discussed or argued about, especially a social or political matter that affects the interests of a lot of people: vấn đề
examples: Abortion is a highly controversial issue.
We should raise the issue of discrimination with the council.
The key issue is whether workers should be classified as ‘employees’.

children.name: discuss/debate an issue
examples: They met to discuss the issue of working conditions at the factory.

children.name: raise an issue/bring up an issue
children.definition: say an issue should be discussed
examples: Some important issues were raised at the meeting.

children.name: deal with/tackle an issue
children.definition: alsoaddress an issueformal
examples: The government must deal with the issue of gun crime.|The company said that it will address the issue at the next scheduled board meeting.

children.name: decide/settle/resolve an issue
children.definition: solve it
examples: The issue was settled after some tough negotiations.|No deadline has been set to resolve the issue.

children.name: face an issue
children.definition: accept that an issue exists and deal with it
examples: Politicians seem to be reluctant to face the issue.

children.name: avoid/evade an issue
children.definition: alsododge/duck an issueinformal
examples: (= avoid discussing an issue )There is no point in evading the issue any longer.

children.name: confuse/cloud/muddy the issue
children.definition: make an issue more difficult to understand or deal with than it needs to be
examples: You must not let your feelings cloud the issue.

children.name: highlight an issue
children.definition: bring attention to it
examples: The minister used his speech to highlight the issue of global warming.

children.name: an issue comes up
children.definition: alsoan issue arisesformal
examples: (= people started to discuss it )The issue arose during a meeting of the Budget Committee.

children.name: the issues surrounding something
examples: This chapter discusses the ethical issues surrounding genetically modified foods.

children.name: a political/social/economic etc issue
examples: They discussed a number of political issues.

children.name: an important issue
examples: The committee met several times to discuss this important issue.

children.name: a key/major/big issue
children.definition: very important
examples: For me, the big issue is cost.

children.name: a difficult/complex issue
examples: He was able to grasp complex issues quickly.

children.name: a controversial/sensitive issue
children.definition: an issue that causes strong feelings and arguments
examples: Abortion is a controversial issue.

children.name: a thorny issue
children.definition: alsoa vexed issueformal
examples: (= a difficult one that causes disagreement )Illegal immigration is always a thorny issue.

children.name: a burning issue
children.definition: a very important and urgent issue
examples: For country-dwellers, transport is a burning issue.

children.name: wider issues
children.definition: more general issues, that affect more people or things
examples: This is a question that raises much wider issues.

children.name: a topical issue
children.definition: an issue that is important at the present time
examples: The magazine discusses topical issues in science.

children.name: the underlying issue
children.definition: the cause, or a more important problem that is related to something
examples: This research explores some of the underlying issues related to high unemployment.

children.name: a fundamental issue
children.definition: a basic and important issue
examples: Decisions still need to be made about some fundamental issues.

children.name: an unresolved issue
children.definition: that has not been dealt with
examples: A number of unresolved issues remain before the treaty can be signed.

children.name: a range of issues
examples: A range of issues were debated at the meeting.

children.name: something is not the issuespoken
children.definition: something is not the most important problem or part
examples: Price alone is not the issue.

children.name: question
children.definition: a difficult subject or problem that has often been discussed but still needs to be solved: nghi vấn, vấn đề
examples: The real question here is how can we integrate asylum seekers into communities.
How can we best help less developed countries? That’s the really important question.

children.name: raise a question
children.definition: bring it to people’s attention
examples: This study raises several important questions.

children.name: address a question
children.definition: start trying to deal with it
examples: Two questions need to be addressed.

children.name: discuss a question
examples: They discussed the question of the possible use of the atomic bomb.

children.name: consider a question
examples: We must also consider the question of compensation.

children.name: deal with a question
examples: This question will be dealt with in Chapter 4.

children.name: tackle a question
children.definition: try to deal with a difficult question
examples: Who has the ability to tackle the tough questions facing the nation?

children.name: resolve a question
children.definition: deal with it in a satisfactory way
examples: We will proceed just as soon as we can resolve the question of the fee.

children.name: an important/big question
examples: The book raises important questions about nationality and the role of a citizen.

children.name: a fundamental question
examples: Their experiences have highlighted fundamental questions of human rights.

children.name: serious questions
examples: The incident has raised serious questions about police conduct.

children.name: a vexed/thorny question
children.definition: one that is hard to deal with
examples: Finally, there’s the thorny question of money.

children.name: a burning question
children.definition: an important one that needs dealing with
examples: Little progress was made on the burning question of Africa’s debt.

children.name: a moral/ethical question
children.definition: one relating to principles of what is right and wrong
examples: This area of medical research poses serious ethical questions that doctors alone cannot answer.

children.name: unanswered/open
children.definition: not dealt with
examples: At this point a key question remains unanswered.

children.name: question of
examples: We discussed the question of confidentiality.
The question isshould I take the job in Japan, or should I stay here?

children.name: matter
children.definition: a subject or situation that you have to think about or deal with:
examples: There are important matters we need to discuss.

children.name: a serious/important matter
examples: It is a very serious matter to mislead the police.

children.name: an urgent matter
children.definition: something that needs to be dealt with quickly

children.name: a weighty matter
children.definition: an important matter
examples: I was surprised that this weighty matter was decided so quickly.

children.name: a small/trivial matter
children.definition: a matter that is not important
examples: Walking out over such a small matter may seem ridiculous.

children.name: a simple/easy matter
children.definition: something that is easy to do
examples: Putting together the bookcases is a fairly simple matter.

children.name: a personal/private matter
examples: We never spoke about personal matters.

children.name: a financial/legal/religious etc matter
examples: This is a legal matter and should be discussed with a solicitor.

children.name: a practical matter
examples: He wrote to him several times about practical matters to do with the house.

children.name: discuss the matter
examples: She refused to discuss the matter.

children.name: raise the matter
children.definition: with somebody
examples: (= discuss something with someone )If you need further training, raise the matter with your manager.

children.name: consider the matter
children.definition: think about something

children.name: settle/resolve the matter
children.definition: decide something
examples: They are meeting tonight to settle the matter.

children.name: pursue the matter
children.definition: keep discussing or asking about something
examples: She decided not to pursue the matter, as it obviously upset him.

children.name: investigate the matter
children.definition: try to find out the truth about something
examples: The police said they were investigating the matter.

children.name: let the matter rest/drop
children.definition: stop discussing or worrying about something
examples: I was too curious to let the matter drop.

children.name: a matter of importance
children.definition: something important
examples: He consulted her on all matters of importance.

children.name: a matter of concern
children.definition: something that concerns people
examples: Safety standards in the industry have become a matter of concern.

children.name: a matter for debate/negotiation/discussion
children.definition: something to be debated/negotiated etc
examples: How to solve the housing crisis is a matter for debate.

children.name: a matter for speculation/conjecture
children.definition: something people discuss and wonder about
examples: His future had become a matter for speculation.

children.name: be a matter for somebody
children.definition: to decide
examples: (= be something that a particular person should decide )This is a matter for the judge.

children.name: the matter at hand
children.definition: alsothe matter in handBritish English
examples: (= the thing you are dealing with now )Do not let yourself be distracted from the matter in hand.

children.name: be no laughing matter
children.definition: be something serious and important, though it might seem funny
examples: A doctor’s bad handwriting is no laughing matter, because it can lead to errors.

children.name: the heart/crux of the matter
children.definition: the most important part of something
examples: The crux of the matter is: how do we prevent these floods from happening again?

children.name: matters arising from/out of something
children.definition: things connected with or caused by a particular event
examples: Are there any matters arising from the report which you wish to discuss?

children.name: matter for
examples: The legal arrangements for the sale are a matter for negotiation.

children.name: Register
examples: Matteris used especially in formal or official contexts. In everyday English, people usually usesubject, or just sayit:
I’ve talked to him aboutthe matter.➔I’ve talked to him aboutit.

children.name: affair
children.definition: vấn đề, công việc
examples: a)public or political events and activities :
Are you interested in world affairs?

children.name: world/international affairs
examples: China is now a major player in world affairs.

children.name: current affairs
children.definition: important events that are happening now
examples: a 24-hour news and current affairs channel

children.name: sb’s private affairs
children.definition: things that are personal and not for other people to know about
examples: He never discussed his private affairs in public.

children.name: sb’s financial affairs
examples: They offer advice on managing your financial affairs.

children.name: sb’s business affairs
examples: After dad retired, I managed his estate and business affairs.

children.name: economic affairs
examples: He was appointed Minister of State with responsibility for economic affairs.

children.name: political affairs
examples: The military promised to stay out of political affairs.

children.name: religious affairs
examples: She wanted to be more involved in the church and religious affairs.

children.name: foreign/external affairs
children.definition: events in other countries
examples: the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs

children.name: domestic/internal affairs
children.definition: alsohome affairsBritish English
examples: (= events inside a country )the Minister of Home Affairs|He said that the US should not try to interfere in his country's domestic affairs.

children.name: public affairs
children.definition: events that affect the people of a country
examples: He was active in public affairs in his region.

children.name: affairs of state
children.definition: the business of the government
examples: The church played no role in the affairs of state.

children.name: put your affairs in order
children.definition: organize them before you go somewhere or die
examples: I have cancer so I know I’ve got to put my affairs in order.

children.name: the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
examples: Women had little role in public affairs.
b)things connected with your personal life, your financial situation etc :
I am not prepared to discuss my financial affairs with the press.
He's alwaysmeddling in(= trying to influence) other people's affairs.

children.name: military affairsthe president’s advisor on military affairs
term
children.definition: xét về mặt nào đó
examples: 1 in terms of somethingif you explain or describe something in terms of a particular fact or event, you are explaining or describing it only in relation to that fact or event
describe/measure/evaluate etc sth in terms of sth
Femininity is stilldefined in terms ofbeauty.
It’s a mistake tothink ofFlorida onlyin terms ofits tourist attractions.
It’s too early to starttalking in terms ofcasualties.
In terms of money, I was better off in my last job.
in terms of what/how/who etc
Did the experiment find any differences in terms of what children learned?
2 in general/practical/financial etc termsused to show that you are describing or considering a subject in a particular way or from a particular point of view
in general/broad/simple etc terms
In financial terms, the project was not a success.
We explain in simple terms what the treatment involves.
It would be wrong to describe societypurely ineconomicterms.
The war, although successfulin military terms, left the economy in ruins.
What do these statistics meanin human terms?
in sb’s terms
In our terms, the scheme has not been a success.
in real/absolute terms(= accurate, true, or including any related changes )
Rail fares have fallen 17 per cent in real terms.
in relative terms(= compared with other, similar things )
Students have less money in relative terms, but spend more on books.

children.name: point
children.definition: a single fact, suggestion, detail etc that is part of a subject being considered, discussed, or written about: điểm
examples: That’s a very interesting point.
She made some extremely good points.
There are three important points we must bear in mind.
This brings me to my next point.

children.name: a good point
examples: I think that’s a very good point.

children.name: an interesting point
examples: He has made an interesting point.

children.name: an important point
examples: That’s an important point to bear in mind.

children.name: a serious point
examples: He’s making a joke but there is a serious point there as well.

children.name: a valid point
examples: She raised a number of valid points.

children.name: a general point
examples: I’d like to make one further general point.

children.name: a similar point
examples: Kevin Phillips made a similar point in his 1993 book, ‘Boiling Point’.

children.name: the main point
examples: Finally, I will summarise the main points of this chapter.

children.name: one final/last point
examples: There is one final point I would like to make.

children.name: put/get your point across
children.definition: make people understand it
examples: I think we got our point across.

children.name: raise a point
children.definition: mention it
examples: I was going to raise that point.

children.name: illustrate/demonstrate a point
examples: A simple example will illustrate the point.

children.name: prove your/a point
children.definition: prove that what you say is right
examples: He was determined to prove his point.

children.name: understand a point
examples: I’m sorry, I don’t understand your point.

children.name: see/take/get sb’s point
children.definition: understand or agree with it
examples: OK, I take your point. But it’s not that easy.

children.name: have a point
children.definition: have made a good point
examples: Maybe she has a point.

children.name: labour the pointBritish English,belabor the pointAmerican English
children.definition: keep saying something
examples: I don’t wish to labour the point, but why didn’t you just tell me?

children.name: clarify a point
children.definition: make it clearer
examples: Could you clarify a couple of points for me?

children.name: point taken
children.definition: used to say to someone that you accept what they say
examples: All right, point taken – I should have asked you first.

children.name: the finer points of something
children.definition: the small details
examples: I’m afraid I don’t understand the finer points of the game.

children.name: point about
examples: I agree with John’s point about keeping the costs down.

children.name: make a pointget someone to understand your suggestion, argument etc
examples: He makes the point that predicting behaviour is not easy.

children.name: aspect
children.definition: one part of a subject, problem, etc or one particular way of considering the subject: khía cạnh
examples: Women are interested in the car’s technological aspects just as much as men are.

children.name: an important/significant aspect
examples: A person’s nationality is an important aspect of their identity.

children.name: a key aspect
children.definition: a very important aspect
examples: There have been changes in five key aspects of education.

children.name: a positive aspect
examples: Describe some of the positive aspects of technological development.

children.name: negative aspect
examples: We have to consider tourism’s negative aspects.

children.name: a worrying/disturbing aspect
examples: The worrying aspect is that it gets worse every year.

children.name: the technical/practical/financial etc aspects
examples: The technical aspects of the movie were incredible.

children.name: a striking aspect
examples: This is one of the most striking aspects of life in Tokyo.

children.name: deal with an aspect
examples: International banks have departments to deal with this aspect of trade.

children.name: look at/consider/examine an aspect
examples: Managers were asked to look at every aspect of their work.

children.name: discuss an aspect
examples: Police are reluctant to discuss any aspect of the investigation.

children.name: concentrate/focus on an aspect
examples: Accountants often concentrate on one aspect of accounting.

children.name: cover all aspects of something
examples: The training course covers all aspects of business.

children.name: the health/business/money etc aspectthe health aspects of chemical accidents|
examples: I’m not very interested in the business aspect.

children.name: aspect of
examples: Dealing with people is the most important aspect of my work.
Alcoholism affects all aspects of family life.

children.name: the safety/security aspectthe safety aspect of nuclear power generation
to start talking about a subject
get onto
children.definition: sth to start talking about a subject after talking about sth else that is connected to it in some way:

children.name: get onto the subject/ topic/question of
examples: ▪ How on earth did we get onto the subject of dogs?

children.name: ▪ Whenever Ma got onto that subject, my head would start to spin
to talk about the subject you are supposed to be talking about
get to the point
children.definition: get/come to the point to start talking about the subject you are supposed to be talking about or really want to talk about, especially after you have been talking about sth else: đi vào vấn đề

children.name: ▪ He chatted abut the weather for a while before coming to the point
examples: .▪ ‘We know that already,’ interrupted Steve impatiently. ‘Get to the point’.

children.name: get/come straight/right to the pointget immediately to the point
examples: ▪ She came straight to the point. ‘When do you think you’ll be able to pay me back?
▪ Well, gentlemen, let’s get right to the point.

children.name: stick to the point
children.definition: /keep to the pointBritish  to continue talking only about the subject you are supposed to be talking about, and not talk about things that are not connected with it: bám sát vấn đề
examples: ▪ Can we try, please, to stick to the point - we don’t have much time.
▪ Mike seems to be quite incapable of keeping to the point.

children.name: to the point
children.definition: sth that sb says or writes that isto the point is only about the subject they are supposed to be talking about, and not about anything else: bám sát vấn đề
examples: ▪ The chairman’s speech was short and to the point.
▪ Korean newspapers only have four pages, so stories have to be very much to the point.

children.name: subject matter
children.definition: what is being talked about in speech or writing, or represented in art: đề tài
examples: The movie has been rated ‘R’ due to adult subject matter.
There has been no attempt to arrange the books according to subject matter.
Sagan published a book relating to the subject matter in his TV show.
‘The People versus Larry Flynt’ was given an ‘18’ certificate because it contains adult subject matter.

children.name: subject
children.definition: sth that is talked about or written about, for example at a meeting, in a conversation, discussion, book, film etc: đề
examples: Paul has strong opinions on most subjects.
The subjects covered in this chapter are exercise and nutrition.

children.name: discuss/talk about a subject
examples: Have you discussed the subject with your husband?

children.name: change the subject
children.definition: start talking about something different
examples: She tried to change the subject.

children.name: mention a subject
examples: The subject was not mentioned again.

children.name: deal with/cover a subject
children.definition: speak or write about it
examples: The subject is dealt with in great detail in his previous book.

children.name: touch on a subject
children.definition: say or write a little about it
examples: In his speech, he touched on the subject of death.

children.name: bring up/raise a subject
children.definition: deliberately start talking about it
examples: You brought the subject up, not me.

children.name: get onto a subject
children.definition: happen to start talking about it
examples: We somehow got onto the subject of detective stories.

children.name: broach a subject
children.definition: start talking about a sensitive subject
examples: She hesitated, wondering exactly how to broach the subject of their sleeping arrangements.

children.name: get back to a subject
examples: Somehow I just knew in the end we would get back to the subject of money.

children.name: drop a subject
children.definition: stop talking about it
examples: To her relief, Julius dropped the subject.

children.name: avoid/keep off/stay off a subject
children.definition: not talk about it
examples: I knew he was trying to avoid the subject of drugs.|She hoped that Anna would keep off the subject of Luke for the next few hours.

children.name: get somebody off a subject
children.definition: make them talk about something else
examples: It was difficult to get him off the subject of cars.

children.name: a subject comes up
children.definition: people start talking about it
examples: The subject of payment never came up.

children.name: an interesting/fascinating subject
examples: Fame is a fascinating subject.

children.name: a difficult/complex subject
children.definition: very complicated
examples: Immigration is a complex subject.

children.name: a controversial subject
examples: The content of the curriculum has become a controversial subject.

children.name: a sensitive/touchy subject
children.definition: one that people may get upset about
examples: Steer clear of complicated issues or sensitive subjects.

children.name: a delicate subject
children.definition: one that may be embarrassing
examples: She carefully avoided discussing the delicate subject of money.

children.name: a taboo subject
children.definition: one that it is not acceptable to mention
examples: For them, death was not a taboo subject.

children.name: a subject of/for discussion
examples: TV is a favourite subject for discussion.

children.name: a subject of conversation
examples: She searched for a new subject of conversation.

children.name: a subject of/for debate
children.definition: a subject people discuss and disagree about
examples: The reason for the increased risk of cancer is still a subject of debate.

children.name: a subject of controversy
children.definition: a subject people disagree about strongly
examples: Nuclear power is still the subject of considerable controversy.

children.name: a subject area
children.definition: a group of related subjects
examples: He has written a lot in this subject area.

children.name: subject of
examples: Truffaut’s childhood memories were the subject of his first film.
While we’reon the subject ofmoney, do you have the $10 you owe me?

children.name: on the subject (of sth)about a particular subject: về một chủ đề nào đó
examples: The first book on the subject was published in 1900.
He has very little to say on the subject of the accusations made against him.
►Do not say ‘the subject is about ... ’:The subject of the poem is war.|The poem is about war.

children.name: topic
children.definition: a subject that people often discuss or write about, in books, newspapers, at school etc: chủ đề.Topicis less general than Subject.
examples: The environment is a popular topic these days.
topic of
We shall return to the topic of education in Chapter 7.
topic of conversation/debate etc
The wedding has been the only topic of conversation for weeks.
The maintopic for discussionwill be the proposed new supermarket.
range of topics
a widerange of topics

children.name: a topic of conversation
examples: Her favourite topic of conversation is herself.

children.name: a topic of discussion/debate
examples: The issue is a topic of great debate in the record industry.

children.name: the main topic
examples: The main topics covered are finance, health and leisure.

children.name: an important topic
examples: The legal team will discuss a number of important topics.

children.name: a hot topic
children.definition: one that a lot of people are discussing or arguing about
examples: Gangs and drugs are the hot topics in this district.

children.name: a controversial topic
children.definition: one that causes a lot of disagreement, because many people have strong opinions about it
examples: Abortion is one of the most controversial topics in America today.

children.name: a sensitive topic
children.definition: one that must be dealt with very carefully, because it may offend people
examples: It is unusual for a judge to speak publicly about a sensitive topic such as religion.

children.name: cover a topic
examples: The book covers such topics as business strategy and marketing.

children.name: discuss a topic
examples: We discussed a range of topics.

children.name: raise/bring up a topic
children.definition: start talking about it
examples: It’s still a very difficult topic to raise.

children.name: leave a topic
children.definition: stop talking about it
examples: Before we leave this topic, may I add one more thing.

children.name: thing
children.definition: especially spoken sth that people talk about or think about:
examples: The first thing we have to discuss is the price.
The only thing she ever talks about is her boyfriend.
We talked about the old days and other things.

children.name: business
children.definition: sth that needs to be discussed at abusinessor political meeting: việc cần bàn
examples: Right, could we get started please? We’ve a lot of business to get through this morning.
Okay, let’sget down to business(= start doing or discussing something ).

children.name: any other businessBritish in a meeting, subjects that are not on the list of things to discuss, but that people may want to talk about: còn vấn đề gì, còn chuyện gì nữa không
examples: Is there any other business before we close the meeting?
‘Is thereany other business?’ the chairman asked.

children.name: theme
children.definition: main subject or idea in a piece of writing, speech, film etc: chủ đề, đề tài
examples: The book’s theme is the conflict between love and duty.

children.name: the main/central/dominant theme
examples: The main theme of the book is the importance of honesty.

children.name: a major theme
examples: Cultural change is the second major theme of his work.

children.name: a common theme
examples: Death and rebirth is a common theme in Eliot’s poetry.

children.name: a recurrent/recurring theme
children.definition: one that appears several times
examples: Returning to traditional values was a major theme of the president’s speech.

children.name: an underlying theme
children.definition: one that is important but not very noticeable
examples: One of the book’s underlying themes is the struggle for human rights.

children.name: a universal theme
children.definition: subjects that affect people of all races and cultures
examples: Readers everywhere can relate to the universal themes in his work.

children.name: variations on a theme
children.definition: things with a similar basic subject, style etc
examples: Most of her short stories are variations on the theme of tragedy.

children.name: on that score
children.definition: concerning the particular thing you have just mentioned:
examples: As for the cost, you don’t need to worry on that score.
I'll let you have the money, so there's nothing to worry about on that score.

children.name: "The team has great determination to win, " declared the coach. "I've no doubts on that score."
thesis
children.definition: nounpluraltheseschính đề

children.name: formalthe main idea, opinion or theory of a person, group, piece of writing or speech
examples: _Their main thesis was that war was inevitable.

children.name: in question
children.definition: sb/sthformal the person or thing that is being discussed
examples: I stayed at home on the night in question.
Where were you during the evening in question?
